text: From tap at the brewpub. Pours hazy dark brown with a deep amber glare, creamy and tan head. Aroma is roasted malty, chocolate and caraemel. Creamy mouthfeel. Breadish, dry and slight roasted on the back of the tongue. Dry and mild bitter far finish.
Dark cola color with a creamy off-white head. Aroma of roasted malt and chocolate.Roasted malt and coffee flavor with chocolate sweetness. Nice beer.
On tap at New Hope brewery. Dark brown color. Small creamy tan head. Roasted malt nose. Dry roasted malt flavor. Smooth and creamy. Nicely done.

Triumph over and I love the fact is the most recent version and the best way of saying it is the most recent version and 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap at Triumph brewpub in New Hope, PA. 
 
Opaque, near black with a creamy pale tan head and excellent lacing. 

Aroma of chocolate, roasted malt and coffee. 

Taste of roasted malt, chocolate and coffee. Rather dry. 

Medium/light body and medium/low carbonization.



---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
On tap at New Hope - a very good stout. You can taste the quality. Nice dark color and aroma.

On tap at New Hope brewpub. Pours a clear dark brown/black color with a finger of lingering creamy off white head. Aroma of roasted malts and lots of vanilla. Taste is the same. Roasted malt, chocolate, and vanilla. A little on the thin side for a stout, but one of the better beers I had from the brewpub.

A dark black pour with thick brown head. A creamy, chocolatey, and coffee like aroma. A nice and smooth creamy and coffee flavor that is not overpowering like most stouts. Some hints of roast and nuts as well.

Why do we like stouts ?  Dark appearance.  Extra creamy, full bodied. Not over powering in the coffee character. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Beautiful mahogany, creamy head that lasts. Roasted grain flavor divine. They got it on this one. A winner!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours a dark brown with a creamy tan head.  Smells of coffee, brown bread, roast nuts.  Taste is sweet, moderately bitter - hints of coffee and chocolate, toast - very roasty, with mild floral hops.

UPDATED: JAN 19, 2013 Smells very roasty. Lots of dark malt. Pours with good dose of creamy head with lots of lacing. No sweetness here, it is a very dry stout. Some bitterness, a crisp leave. Medium consistency. On tap at brewpub.

Pours deep brown/black with a creamy tan head...nice nitro cascade...great retention and lacing.  Aroma is roasty with light chocolate.  Flavor has nice chocolate...roasty and nutty.  Mouthfeel is creamy and the finish has nice lightly rooasted chocolate.
On draft at the brewery, Princeton location.  Nice blackish color with a small head.  Would be better on nitro, but overall not bad.  Drinkable and roasty.
Pours dark brown with a thick light brown head. Nice bit of maltiness on the nose. A bit thin on the palate. I was hoping for more of a roasted malty thing going on.

On tap at Triumph.  The best of the batch.  Pours a dark black color with an off white foam head.  Roasty aroma.  Milk stout taste with a nice roastiness to it.  Would rock at a higher abv with a more creamy mouthfeel.
Opaque black with tan head. Strong roast aroma thats almost smoky. Smooth bodied, but not overly so. Moderately bitter and sweet. The best of the seven beers they had on tap.
One of the best beers Triumph brews.  Pours black with tan head.  Aroma is chocolate malts and coffee.  Taste is sweet coffee.  Very drinkable.  On nitro this would be excellent.

There is a subtle dry roasted malty flavor with coffee notes. The appearance is thick and black with a cocoa tan head. The flavor of coffee and roasted malts with a smooth bitter ending. The body is a bit lighter, creamy and easy to drink.
Draft @ princeton. Dark pour with some velvety brown head. Well this stout may be an ode to guiness but it doesnt live up to it, flavor isnt as smooth or drinkable.
Draft.  Pours a black body with a tan head.  Malty chocolate, minerals, and s dry coco finish.  Bitter and roasted malt, with a creamy finish.  Good stuff.

Pours a dark color almost back iwth a good lace and good head retention. The aroma is coffee and burnt toast. The flavor is meaty and smoky and lightly fruity, while maintaining its dryness. This stuff was awesome.

Tap at the Philly location: Deep brown ruby hue with a thick dense creamy tan head. Vacant aroma- some roasted barley and light fruity estery notes (burnt plum). Light fluffy/airy (low carbonation). The flavor is mild but has a touch of smoky character that saves it. The barley roasted and peat-like flavors mesh nicely. Close to being a very nice stout- just a bit lacing in texture and aromatics.

Sampler at the Philly brewery. Roasty smoky nose very clean with little hop aroma. Very dark brown with creamy head off a nitro tap. Roast malts and a bit of smoke in the flavor. Clean dry lightly bitter finish. Great sessionable beer. My favorite of the evening, very well done.

Tap at Philly. Hard to get in to this when the MUSIC IS SO FUCKING LOUD. Super creamy head, nice black color. Dryish chalky roast aroma, creamy greens, with a light creamy body. Nice notes of rye and fresh coffee in the finish. Delicious. Id love to session this one for a while, but not somewhere with such, err, loud music.

On draft at the Philly location. The pour was pretty standard for the style, nice nitro-slow cascading head formation and a dark black body, head fairly dark tan to choco-colored. The aroma was sweet chocolate, some roast. The flavor was dry chocolate, not much roast going on, tobacco, faint coffee notes. The body was full and a little on the sticky side for the style. Decent.

Tap at Philadelphia location.  Pitch black with a creamy thick nitro head.  Aroma is lightly roasty with a bit of soft malt sweetness.  Good palate.  Creamy and thick yet dry and quaffable.  There is a dry cocoa/colaish character through the middle that gives it a unique sort of herbal flavour.  Dry roasty finish.  Theres not much to complain about in this glass.
Poured black with small tan head. Tad bit of coffee and roasted malt aroma. Some roasted malt flavor. Easy drinking stout.

Tap at princeton. Pour is velvet black with a thick nut brown head. Aromas of roasted malts, oats, and some yeast. Flavor is light with roasted malts, bread, and light chocolate. Decent but nothing great.
user_location: back in NJ!, New Jersey, USA

text: Draft at new hope. Pours black with a off-white head. Aroma of roasted malts, coffee and a hint of chocolate. Flavor was roasted coffee, dark malts and a touch of chocolate with a creamy texture and a dry finish.
On draft at Triumph, New Hope. Poured black with khaki head. Roasted malt flavor. Some coffee and chocolate present as well. Finishes dry. Would be better if served on nitrogen.

UPDATED: SEP 15, 2008 In short: A light-on-taste stout with fruity notes.  Easy to drink.
How: Tap at brewpub, Princeton location
The look: Black body topped by a medium beige head leaving good lacing
In long: A whole lotta malts in this one.  A little lactic.  A little grape juice and dried dark fruits.  Medium roastiness level.  Despite its full body the problem with this beer is that it really wasnt tasty, I had to focus to pick-up flavours.  Not sweet but certainly not very dry.  A Triumph it is and it isnt.
UPDATED: MAR 10, 2009 Draft at the brewpub. Brown/black with a beige nitro head. Roasted aroma, a hint of toast and nuts. Nice dry roasted flavor with a light sweetness. Not bad.

Heavy malt flavor, dark, burnt, and strong. Light, resinous hoppy flavor. Moderately yeasty. other favors include rasin, tar, and coffee. Large head, quite creamy. Light brown, excellent lacing, fully lasting. Murky in body, with large particles, and thick density. Dark brown or black in hue. Lightly sweet, lightly bitter, with a long dark finish. dry, creamy texture. softly carbonated. lightly alcoholic - well hidden. A good coffee style stout, tasty, but not on par with a Rogue or Brooklyn.
Smells roasted malts, some smoke barbecue smell, pours near opaque with a creamy beige head, creamy mouthfeel like a guiness with a bit more smoky taste. not bad.

Draft->juice glass ([email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */): Pours a large, lasting, light brown head that exhibits excellent lacing atop a black body.  Malt smells of cookie, but not much aroma beyond this point, like a lot of dry stouts.  The flavors duration is short, being moderately acidic, and ending like sour milk.  The body is light, texture is thin, and the carbonation is flat, all ending astringently.

A good Guinness-attempt.
Nitro at New hope - Blackish pour with a medium, lasting head.  Aroma is dry, chocolatey, and dominated by coffee.  Flavor has a nutty-coffee mix along with some dry roasty malts.  Not bad overall.

Nitro draft at Philly brewpub. Poured deep black, with a creamy beige head. roasted chocolate malt aroma. Rich, roasted malt flavor with chocolate, coffee, and mild hops. Smooth nitro body. Id like this a hell of a lot more without the nitro, but its still a solid dry stout.
Opaque with a tan head.  Aroma is roast with wet cat fur tones.  Sweet, nutty and only lightly roasty.  Nitro.  Flaccid and neutered but drinkable.

Date: 07/26/2007
Mode: Draft, Nitro
Source: Brewpub, Philly

black, creamy tan head, streaks of drippy lace, 
dry roasted and dark chocolate aroma, 
creamy body, 
rich dark chocolate flavor, touch of roasted, touch of sweetness with the creamyness

Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 10/10; Overall: 13/20
Rating: 3.5/5.0Drinkability: 8/10
Score: **+/4

Tap @ Triumph Philly.  Poured an opaque black color with a creamy tan head.  The aroma was filled with coffee and a pleasant roast.  There was some sweetness in the aroma.  The flavor was roasty and semi-sweet.  Smooth nitro mouthfeel.

on tap in Princeton.  Dark brown/almost black with ruby highlights and a creamy tan head.  Aroma is moderate chocolate, light roast and caramel.  Taste is chocolate, sweet caramel, lightly roasty and dusty notes.  Finishes lightly roasty.  A good stout but not as dry as I thought it was going to be.

I got it on tap at the Princeton brewery. I liked the nitro pour; it left a good tan, creamy head that lasted. A stronger malt flavor and not quite as hoppy as the standard Dry Stout, more to my liking. Full bodied, mouth coating with a fine aftertaste.

On tap at Triumph Brewery in Princeton.  Pours a very dark brown with a small tan head.  I smelled nuts, chocolate and malt.  The taste is chocolate, coffee and some malt.  I really enjoyed the dryness of this one...I didnt know what to expect, but the roastiness really does wonders on the palate.  This was the best beer on Tap there.

Draft at Princeton. Nitro pour. Black with creamy brown head that laces down the glass. Light chocolate and roasted malt aroma. Light and creamy mouthfeel. Very much like a Guinness. This has a little more chocolate, and does not have the sour tang. I decent session stout

On tap at NH loc. Cinnamon roast aroma, very nice.  Medium dark brown beer, semisemi translucent. nice extra tight cream head, lacing. flavor is a bit subdued... a little roast, cream.  thin palate, fairly normal to style, luftig, smooth.

Poured a very dark, reddish brown color with a small tan head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of smoke, chocolate, macadamia nuts, and roasted malts.  Taste of chocolate, caramel malts, nuts, and a bitter roasted finish.
on tap-pours a retaining creamy brown head that laces with black color.  Aroma is coffee, sweet.  Taste is coffee, sweet, slight bitter finish.  Medium body, minimal carbonation.  Not my taste.

Draft at Princeton. Great looking stout that could easily pass for a creamy Guinness. Aroma is nutty and chocolaty. Taste has a lot of chocolate, maybe a bit too much dare I say. Dry but not dry enough but full flavored none the less. Not bad.

On tap at New Hope. Dark brown color with a large tan head. Mild roasted malt aroma and flavor that would appeal to most Guinness drinkers. Has the same nitro pour, good looks, mild flavor, creamy but thin mouthfeel. Boring, but solid and a good beer to introduce people to stouts.
Nice and dry as an Irish Dry should be.  Good backbone and long lasting head made this one an admirable drink among the many lackluster offerings here.

Nitro tap at New Hope:  Pours a deep black with a thick creamy beige head.  Aroma has a light to medium roasted barley/coffee with hints of chocolate.  Flavor is light but has some chocolate and dark malts along with more coffee and some toffee.  Smooth and creamy mouthfeel, with a light body.

Poured very dark brown with a thick off white head.  Very creamy appearance with long head rentention.  Smelled like bitter chocolate, coffee and espresso.  Roasty.  Tasted like bitter coffee and chocolate with a bitterness that worked pretty well.  Very creamy palate which was not overdone on the roastiness.  Overall this was a good session stout.

10.16.04  Nitro tap @ Princeton.  Really dark brown, like semi-sweet chocolate, but just not black; big, thick, creamy, nitro induced head.  Cascades just like any similar beer.  The aromas are very mild roasted malts, coffe-ish; one-dimensional.  Flavor is lackluster, mild bitterness, an off-putting aftertaste.  The body is wet and  just a notch above thin - right on the mark, really.  I bet they sell a ton of this stuff.

Very nice pour, off white head with cascading goodness all around.  Dark as night.
Aroma of slightly burnt coffee.  Medium bodied mouthfeel, the flavors and aromas all come together very well.
Smooth it is.  Nice clean finish.  Super!

Reminded me of coffee ice cream.  Heavy, but not tremendously so.  Good color, but not perfect fidelity of color (who wants that in a homey brew anyway).  Not Guiness at all, and not terribly distinctive, but one of the better irish stouts Ive had.
Really nice stout, but Im not a huge fan of the dry ones.  "better than guinness" as we say
UPDATED: JUN 18, 2006 Deep brown in color with a nice fluffy head. Roasty chocolate and coffee aroma.Malty and roasty flavor.  Full bodied beer. Smooth and creamy. Very drinkable. Very good.
Tap at New Hope location. Deep brown with tan head. Roasty chocolate and coffe aroma. Full bodied roasty coffe and chocolate flavor. Nice and easy drinking.
user_location: Good Beer Bar Deprived, New Jersey, USA

text: A very good stout.  Creamy smooth with just the right amount of hops to balance.
Nice chocolate head that sticks to the glass.  Black as night.  Milky smooth, but a bit thin.  Good chocolate/coffee flavorings.
Malt and coffee aroma. Black with brussels lace leaving. Grainy and malty taste but very light. Strange aftertaste.
Burnt charcoal nose and tastes. Dark red-black color. Agressive roasted malt taste with espresso tones. Thin body though.
Very much like a guinness or murphys stout, nice black appearance, very smooth, creamy rich white head...couldnt get enough of this one
